p: Data from ARV drug testing and self-report of prior positive HIV status also allowed us to assess whether some of the participants in HPTN 074 may have had transmitted HIV drug resistance (TDR). We detected resistance mutations in samples from 10 (5.6%) of 177 newly-diagnosed participants (6 from Indonesia; 0 from Ukraine; 4 from Vietnam); in all 10 cases, the mutations identified were included in a list of mutations recommended for assessing TDR ( hivdb.stanford.edu/s/who). These 10 participants could have had TDR. TDR has been associated with a higher risk of virologic failure among PWID starting ART [ 26]. In previous reports from Asia, the prevalence of TDR among PWID was 4.0–7.7% (Vietnam: 4.10–7.69% in 2014 [ 27], 4.0% in 2015 [ 28]; Indonesia: <5.0% in 2009 [ 29]). These rates are similar to TDR rates of 2.9%-5.4% reported for PWID in Europe [ 30– 32] and Taiwan [ 33], and Canada [ 34] and are lower than the rate of TDR reported among PWID in Iran (~15%) [ 35]. However, the type of cohort used to assess TDR (e.g., newly-infected individuals, ART-naïve individuals) and the methods used for resistance testing could impact the reported prevalence of TDR.
